context: [3] Analysis of a recombinant inbred line (RIL) mapping population derived from a cross between PI and Sal  identified a major quantitative trait locus (QTL) associated with the high-temperature germination (HTG) trait . [4] Here, we report further genetic and transcriptomic data that strongly support a role for ethylene signaling, and specifically of a lettuce homolog of ETHYLENE RESPONSE FACTOR1 (LsERF1), in the thermotolerance of PI seeds during high-temperature imbibition. [5] Supporting physiological studies indicate that ethylene and LsERF1 may act through the promotion of GA biosynthesis. [6] These results expand upon prior knowledge of the hormonal basis of seed dormancy and connect ethylene action with GA biosynthesis to counter the inhibitory effect of ABA in regulating the sensitivity of lettuce seed germination to elevated temperatures. [1] Screening seed germination of the parental Sal and PI lines across a range of temperatures revealed significant differences in their sensitivities to inhibition. [2] Both Sal and PI seeds germinated 100% at temperatures below 28Â°C, but Sal seeds exhibited thermoinhibition between 29Â°C and 30Â°C, above which germination was completely prevented, while PI seeds exhibited 100% germination up to 32Â°C and were only completely inhibited at 34Â°C (Fig. 1). [3] At 20Â°C, the PI seeds germinated 2 to 3 h earlier than those of Sal; at 30Â°C, only PI seeds germinated and did so at a more rapid rate than at 20Â°C (Supplemental Fig. S1).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, ethylene (referred to as ethene) is linked to the regulation of seed germination under high-temperature conditions, where it interacts with the hormone gibberellin (GA) to counteract the inhibitory effects of abscisic acid (ABA). The study suggests that ethylene signaling, particularly through the ETHYLENE RESPONSE FACTOR1 (LsERF1), plays a crucial role in promoting germination despite elevated temperatures, indicating that inhibitors like ABA can negatively affect this process. Thus, ethylene acts as a promoter against the inhibitory effects of ABA on seed germination.
